Kural_Info.Tamil_Text: சொல்லப் பயன்படுவர் சான்றோர் கரும்புபோல்கொல்லப் பயன்படும் கீழ்.
Kural_Info.English_Meaning: The great bestow (their alms) as soon as they are informed; (but) the mean, like the sugar-cane, only when they are tortured to death.

Layered_Composition.Midground: On the left, a great, virtuous person ('சான்றோர்'). A needy person simply speaks to them ('சொல்ல'). Instantly, the great person produces a stream of golden coins, representing their immediate, willing help.
Layered_Composition.Background: On the right, a base person ('கீழ்') who also has wealth. To get any benefit from them, they are shown being crushed like a sugarcane ('கரும்பு போல் கொல்ல') in a massive press. Only under this extreme, destructive pressure do they release a small, grudging trickle of benefit.

Art_Direction.Subject_and_Action: A sharp contrast in how to get help from the virtuous and the base: the virtuous give freely when simply told of a need, while the base yield benefit only when crushed and destroyed like a sugarcane.
Art_Direction.Symbolic_Motifs: The willing, golden stream of help from the virtuous contrasts with the forced, painful trickle from the base. The sugarcane press is a direct and visceral metaphor for the violence and pressure required to extract anything from the base.
Art_Direction.Mood_and_Emotion: Willing vs. forced, generous vs. miserly, destructive extraction.
Art_Direction.Lighting_and_Color: The virtuous scene is bathed in a warm, golden light of generosity. The scene with the base person is dark, violent, and mechanical, lit by the harsh light of the crushing press.

Technical_Cues.Camera: A powerful diptych shot that presents the two contrasting methods of giving.
Technical_Cues.Resolution: 8K, hyper-realistic, with strong textural details on the sugarcane press.
Technical_Cues.Lighting: Contrasting lighting to show the difference between willing charity and forced extraction.
